verses.text: I rejoiced with those who said to me, "Let us go to the house of the LORD."
Our feet are standing in your gates, O Jerusalem.
Jerusalem is built like a city that is closely compacted together.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 122
rsbNotes.text:
Ps. 122 This “Song of Ascents” records the decision of the poet to accompany a group on a visit to Jerusalem. The psalm describes the glories of Jerusalem, where God is worshiped and where the dynasty of David rules (2 Sam. 7), asking God to protect the city and its inhabitants.

This psalm is similar to the “Zion” songs which extol the city of Jerusalem (46; 48; 76). Jerusalem was prized above other cities because God chose to reveal Himself there to His people. Since Christ has come, God’s people can meet Him in Christ anywhere on the face of the earth (John 4:19–23). Jerusalem represents all believers (Gal. 4:26), and it typifies the coming New Jerusalem (Rev. 21:9–27).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 122:1
rsbNotes.text: 122:1 I. David is the speaker, although the circumstances of composition are not revealed. Later the psalm would be appropriate for pilgrims going to Jerusalem, as for one of the major festivals (Ex. 23:14–19).

verses.text: That is where the tribes go up, the tribes of the LORD, to praise the name of the LORD according to the statute given to Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 122:4
rsbNotes.text: 122:4 as was decreed for Israel. Perhaps a reference to the law of centralization of worship (Deut. 12), or to laws connected with the annual festivals.

verses.text: There the thrones for judgment stand, the thrones of the house of David.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 122:5
rsbNotes.text: 122:5 thrones for judgment. The king was the paramount judge in the land, and Jerusalem was the political as well as religious capital of Israel.

verses.text: Pray for the peace of Jerusalem: "May those who love you be secure.
May there be peace within your walls and security within your citadels."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 122:6
rsbNotes.text: 122:6 peace. The well-known Hebrew term shalom, which denotes wholeness and health. The prayer is for absence of war and for prosperity and growth.

verses.text: For the sake of my brothers and friends, I will say, "Peace be within you."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 122:8
rsbNotes.text: 122:8 For my brothers and companions’ sake. The psalm promotes a sense of community among the people of God. Ultimately, Jerusalem is not bricks and mortar, but people in relationship with one another and with God.

verses.text: For the sake of the house of the LORD our God, I will seek your prosperity.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 122:9
rsbNotes.text: 122:9 the house of the Lord our God. The temple building stands for the presence of God in the midst of the people of God.
